div.l: And namely ther was a grete College
Men clepe the Scoler halle of Cambregge
There was her whete ⁊and her malt y ground
And on a day it happend in a stound
Seke lay the Maunciple on a maladye
Men wend wisly that he shuld dye
For which this Milner͗e stale boþ mele ⁊and corn̄
An hundird times more than he did beforn̄
For though before he stale but curteisly
Now he was a theef outragiously
For which the warden chid ⁊and made fare
But therof sette not the Milner a tare
He crakid bost and seid it nas nat so
Then were ther yong poure scolers two
That duelt in the halle of which I sey
Testive they were and lusti forto pley
And onli for her myrth and reuelrye
Vpon the warden bisili they crye
To yeue hem leue a litle stound
To go to mylle to se her corn̄ y groıı̄und
And hardily they durst ley her necke
The Milner shuld not stele halue a pekke
Of corn̄ by sleight ne by force hem̄ reve
And at last the warden yaue hem leve
Iohn hight that one and Aleyn hiȝt þat oþ̉er
Of one tovn̄ were they born̄ þat hiȝt Stroþ̉er
Ferre in the north I can not telle where
This Aleyn makith al redy his gere
And on an hors he cast his sacke anon̄
Furth goth Aleyn the clerc and eke Iohn
With good Swerd and bokeler by her side
Iohn knew the wey him nedith no gide
And at Mille the sacke adoun̄ he leith
Aleyn spake first alheil Simond in faith
Hou faris thy fare dought̉ir and thy wif
Aleyn welcom coth Symkin be my lif
And Iohn also · hou now what don ye her͗e
By god coth Iohn nede hase na pere
Him behoues to ʆserue himselūue þat has na swayn̄
Or ellis he is a fule as clerkis sayn̄
Oure Maunciple I hoop wil be deed
Swa wurkis ay the wangis in his hede
And therfore I is comen and eke Aleyn̄
